awd_titl_txt: SCH: EXP: Continuous Patient Monitoring in the Emergency Department: A Wearable Device Technology Enabled Dynamic Decision Support Model
awd_abstract_narration:
The objective of the proposed exploratory project is to develop a dynamic mathematical decision support (DS) model for patient prioritization in the Emergency Department (ED).  This model will integrate the use of wearable devices that collect patients' vital signs in real time and decision theory to account for patients' changes while they wait.  The research will focus on the design and application of integrated systems for decision making by merging the mathematical models with the Emergency Severity (ESI) Index and wearable devices. 

The objective of the proposed exploratory project is to develop a dynamic mathematical decision support (DS) model for patient prioritization in the Emergency Department (ED).  The coupling of technology and decision theory can help reduce the level of uncertainty that is inherent to the decision making process of triage nurses. The mathematical models will combine Multi-attribute Utility Theory (MAUT) with fuzzy logic and decision trees to predict patients' criticality and priority using the Emergency Severity Index (ESI) as baseline. In addition, the MAUT model will be enhanced to incorporate attribute changes over time. Wearable devices will be used to collect patients' vital signs in real time; this information will be integrated into mathematical decision models to assist nurses in data gathering, analysis, sorting and presentation. Nurses will be presented with organized information regarding the status of the patients in a meaningful manner that would allow them to notice and respond to any significant changes in patients' status. This research will aid the triage process, especially in extremely busy emergency rooms where re-assessment is difficult if not impossible, putting patients at risk for undetected deterioration.

por.por_cntn:
Emergency Departments (EDs) in the United States (US) use triage systems to sort patients by severity of illness or injury. Current triage systems are based on nurses' initial triage, which could include assessing patient vital signs when patients arrive at the ED. Healthcare researchers have suggested improvements to the current triage system; however, a major drawback is its dependency on the vital indicators originally measured by ED nurses and not followed sequentially over the usually critical waiting period. Therefore, a clinical decision support system that incorporates continuous vital signs monitoring and descriptive information to detect changes in patient conditions and identify patients with deteriorating conditions is needed.

 The primary goal of this research project was to develop a dynamic mathematical decision support model for patient prioritization in the ED.  The proposed decision support model consists of a patient monitoring device, a wireless networking system, and a mathematical decision support system (DSS). The model integrated the use of wearable devices that collected participants' vital signs in real-time and decision theory to account for patients' changes while they wait. 

A non-parametric regression model was created as the mathematical DSS to predict patient priority using the Emergency Severity Index (ESI) as a baseline. We used historical data of 3 years of visits to the ED of a partnering hospital (data was pre-COVID 19). The non-parametric model was created using Multi Adaptive Regression Spines (MARS). Decision trees were also created to visualize patterns in the data. The regression model resulted in a good fit, considering it used real human data. The model resulted in a coefficient of determination of 45.45% (adjusted) with a correct detection of 70.21% for independent test data.

The non-parametric model was compared against a generalized linear model (GLM) and a model developed using multi-attribute utility theory (MAUT). Both the GLM and MAUT models proved reasonable, but the MARS model was more robust than the GLM and required less input from nurses than the MAUT model.

After extensive research on current monitoring systems, we decided to use the CareTaker 4 Wireless Vital Signs Monitor, manufactured by Caretaker Medical, a company based in Charlottesville, Virginia, USA. The CareTaker is an FDA-approved wearable device. It is a cardiovascular monitoring device with the advantages of measuring, in a non-invasive and continuous way, blood pressure, heart rate, and respiration rate.

 After data collection from the CareTaker, we extract the CVS files containing the vital signs information. To analyze the data and apply the mathematical model for triage, we converted a CSV file into a type of stream database called InfluxDB. The migration script was conducted and standardized for each new data submission. The mathematical model was translated into Python, and we ran the script every time we had new data to obtain an updated triage number of each participant.

 We decided to use Grafana as a visualization tool for dashboard creation that allows visualizing real-time and historical stream data that comes from the InfluxDB database. Because we already had the data in InfluxDB, we explored the possibility of getting Grafana embedded in our web system. We came up with an integration that involves dashboards for each patient to monitor the vital signs. The integration was made for all vital signs of the current patients in the system. Even if the patient is not in the ED anymore, the historical data can be visualized. We created a multilevel query to get the different patients' information inside the website. The website was developed in React JS using PHP. A tool to show the mathematical model's results developed in Python was also needed. We also developed a database in MySQL to store the triage results and show them on the website.

 This research presents a successful proof of concept of coupling wearable devices with decision theory to continuously monitor patients. This system can help prioritize patients and address shortcomings in current ESI methods and triage systems. Four shortcomings that the proposed use of wearable devices and decision theory can address include (1) continuous patient monitoring; (2) reduced subjectivity in triage assessment and uncertainty; (3) prioritization on a first-come first-based basis within an ESI priority group; (4) constant feedback for nurses on their prioritization decisions.

 Future research should look further into the implementation approach for the proposed decision support model, which will help gain user acceptance and realize all the model's benefits. Likewise, evaluating the impacts on nurses and patients should participate in the usability and implementation plan.
